definition: to quarrel/to make a noise/noisy/to disturb by making a noise
mouth/classifier for things with mouths (people, domestic animals, cannons, wells etc)/classifier for bites or mouthfuls
few/less/to lack/to be missing/to stop (doing sth)/seldom
to quarrel/to have a row/quarrel/CL:頓|顿[dun4]
to shout and scream (idiom); to kick up a fuss/to make a scene
to make a lot of noise/to be disorderly
to wake sb up with a noise

sentences.english: They had an argument and split-up.
We had been doing business with each other for years before we quarrelled.
sentences.chinese: 在吵翻之前，我们多年来在业务上一直来往。

sentences.english: His lawyer said Underwood had gone to see his girlfriend and wanted to finish a domestic argument.
sentences.chinese: 他的律师替他辩护道，他是去找女友了，想把架吵完。

sentences.english: She ranted and raved for two whole days and wouldn't listen to reason.
sentences.chinese: 她大叫大嚷吵了整整两天，什么也听不进去。

sentences.english: 'What do they quarrel about?' queried Ruth 'Ask me another. '.
sentences.chinese: “他们在吵什么？”鲁思问。“我也不知道。”。

sentences.english: Younger and younger children are clamoring for cell phones.
sentences.chinese: 越来越小的孩子吵着要手机。

sentences.english: Marketing andadvertising folk may be noisy, but we are not stupid.
sentences.chinese: 营销和广告人员可能会很吵，但是我们并不愚蠢。

sentences.english: Seen was particularly cranky and quarreled with another little boy.
sentences.chinese: 肖恩的脾气特别暴燥，他和另一个小男孩吵了起来。

sentences.english: Honestly, it was our most dramatic marital fight to date.
sentences.chinese: 说实话，这是我们结婚来吵得最凶的一次。

sentences.english: They are locked together in a fierce quarrel over a trivial matter.
sentences.chinese: 他们为了一点小事而吵得难分难解。

sentences.english: Or maybe they can’t hear what their friends are saying when it gets too loud.
sentences.chinese: 又或者是太吵的时候它们听不到他们的朋友说什么。

sentences.english: Further dispute would worsen your relations.
sentences.chinese: 再吵下去会使你们的关系恶化。

sentences.english: The two partners split after a quarrel.
sentences.chinese: 这两个合伙人吵了一架之后分成道扬镳了。

sentences.english: I was crazy about the stars, and pestered my father into buying me a telescope.
sentences.chinese: 我对星星着了迷，吵着要我爸爸买一架望远镜。

sentences.english: They have like a two second rebound rate and you're back doing the next pain-in-the-ass thing.
sentences.chinese: 不好两秒钟我们就和好如初然后我们接着再吵。

sentences.english: The boy was at loggerheads with his parents over his long hair and untidy clothes.
sentences.chinese: 男孩和他的父母因长发和不整洁的衣着吵了起来。

definition: to quarrel/to have a row/quarrel/CL:頓|顿[dun4]
to make a lot of noise/to be disorderly
to shout and scream (idiom); to kick up a fuss/to make a scene
noisy/cacophonous/to make noise/to disturb/to vent (feelings)/to fall ill/to have an attack (of sickness)/to go in (for some activity)/to joke
to be difficult with sb/to provoke disagreement/at loggerheads/to fall out with
to be at loggerheads/to have a falling out
to disturb/to create confusion/to make a din
to dispute/to disagree/to argue opinionatedly/to wrangle
to hurl abuse/to trade insults/slanging match
